course.subject: LIFS
course.name: Human Genetics and Personalized Medicine
course.description: Many variations in the human population such as hair thickness, tolerance to milk in adults, high blood cholesterol and susceptibility to certain types of cancer can be determined by genetic factors. This course will cover the principles and up to date technologies for the discovery and analysis of human genetic variation. The application of basic scientific knowledge in a clinical setting will be discussed.
course.prerequisites: LIFS 2210 OR LIFS 3140

reviews.author: Kabul
reviews.title: Take this for fun ;)
reviews.comment_content:
This is an advanced genetics course covering the principles and the technologies to discover and analyze genetic variations in the human population, including hair thickness, lactose persistence, etc.

We're also taught with a couple of useful biotech tools, namely the UCSC Genome Browser and the NCBI Variation Viewer, and also a number of places to search for information, such as SNPedia, ClinVar, PubMed, etc. Overall a very intensive, research-oriented course. I believe you can't find another LIFS course like this even in the 4000-level.

reviews.comment_teaching: Both instructors are competent, knowledgeable in their areas and good in delivery. They are really dedicated in enhancing our skills in doing research and delivering presentations. This is what makes this course stand out from other rote memorization-based LIFS courses.

      üí¨ 10% Group

‚úèÔ∏è 35% Group Project Summary

The final exam was cancelled due to the political turmoil in Hong Kong, and it was changed into a 3-page individual writing to summarize the whole group project.

Rumors has it that it's a bad grade course, and I ended up in a B. But maybe that was my fault cuz I submitted the data mining assignment late.

And indeed, take this course for fun. Don't focus on the grade. üôÉ
reviews.comment_workload:
Lighter workload compared to previous years without the final exam.

The data mining assignment was an individual report with no longer than 4 pages of texts. We needed to identify a suite of 5 SNPs to serve as a diagnostic test for one of the followings:

üî∂ Hemochromatosis
üî∂ Leigh syndrome (complex I deficiency)
üî∂ Thyrotoxic periodic paralysis
üî∂ Tuberous sclerosis

We were required to describe the backgrounds of the diseases and explain the rationale for choosing our collection of SNPs in the diagnostic test. We could talk about the prevalence of the SNPs in a population, the conservation of the SNPs in other species, experimental models and the disruption of functions of a protein implicated in the disease.

BTW don't get confused. "Data mining" here is about the use of tools like Variation Viewer and other public databases. It has nothing to do with computer science or coding.

We also needed to conduct a group project on one of the case studies. We received 1 or 2 pages of information, usually including a pedigree, traits and other characteristics of a rare genetic disease in advance. Based on the information we needed to correctly identify the disease and the gene associated, review publicly available databases and primary literature, explore variants and relate the gene function to the disease.

The group project summary was basically a recap of what was mentioned in the group project.

reviews.author: kjung
reviews.title: Lets keep it updated
reviews.comment_content:
Prof Ho Yi
1. Overview of human genetics
2. How mutations alter the function
3. Human population genetics
4. Mitochondrial defects
5. Imprinting

Prof Tom
6. Technologies for genetic variation discovery

Prof Ho Yi

The order is in the lecture order.

Materials are familiar but go in-depth. Especially everything is connected with genetics so the course really focuses on seeing things related with the genetics behind.

Like others have mentioned, it is like no other course in the LIFS section. Borrowing from what prof Tom said, "This course is not difficult. It's different". Quite relatable. (I'm built differentüòè)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Both professors are excellent. They are very interactive and answer any questions that are raised during the class.

The lecture first started with professor Ho Yi. By now you guys must have encountered him in other lectures. He teaches with good humour and keeps the mood of the whole course light.

Professor Tom also keeps the class very interactive. Especially, he will introduce you to how to use the Genome Browser. He explains things in great detail so you may want to focus on that

Again both professors are excellent and great at teaching.
reviews.comment_grading:
Group project oral presentation 15% (Group: 10%, Individual: 5%)
Group project written report 15%(individual)
Data mining assignment 25%
Final written exam 45% (Open book)

No idea how much I got except for the group presentation (14.5/15). In the end, I got a good grade so I don't think the gradings were that harsh.
reviews.comment_workload:
Have to admit it is not an easy course. But if you know what to study it's not difficult at all. The first impression of the whole class is like the elite kids who are already so engaged with their own experiments and projects take this course. I had no experience with lab or anything and was first time using genome browser, clinvar, uniprot, etc. But because professors explain things very clearly, as long as you focus during the class, you will be able to score well.

Group project: your topic is given a week before your presentation date. You will be given with a genetic disease so you will have to talk about how such mutations (variants) lead to different phenotypes (pathogenic). Groups of 3.

Group project written report: Write script for each slide. Even if that is not your part, you make your own script and submit the presentation with the script in the notes.

Data mining assignment: 4 genetic diseases is provided to the whole class. Choose one disease and find out 5 SNPs that can be used to diagnose if the patient is having the disease. No longer than 4 pages

Please don't get intimidated by what I have written here. I also had no idea what to do and did not understand what they want me to do. But professors will help you out and you will get things done without yourself realizing it.

Good luck!

reviews.author: Kailee
reviews.title: Good to take if you are really interested, but not for those who only want a good grade
reviews.comment_content:
L1: Overview of human genetics
L2: How mutations alter function I
L3: How mutations alter function II
L4: Human population genetics I
L5: Human population genetics II
L6: Mitochondrial defects
L7: Imprinting
L8: Case study I: human with too much or too little fat
L9: Case study I: human with too much or too little fat
L10-11: Case study II: failure to perceive the environment
L12: Technologies for genetic variation discovery I
L13: Technologies for genetic variation discovery II
L14: Prenatal genetic screening: at the bench
L15-16: Case study III: unwanted reaction to specific food
L17-18: Case study IV: muscular dystrophy
L19-20: Case study V: susceptibility to cancer
L20 onwards: group presentation

Mak's ppt does not has much slides, but a lot of graphs instead. He likes to illustrate them in the lesson and answer everyone's question. Thus it is very important to attend his lectures and make notes, or you might miss a lot of details / cannot understand while self studying. Tom's ppt has more details which could support self study. But I still suggest you to attend the lectures as they are both very good teachers who explain ideas in an interesting way.
reviews.comment_teaching: They like to elaborate a lot and try to influence students by asking meaningful questions. In general it helps a lot if you want to pursue a research career in the future as they want to train students to think in a scientific way. They want to guide students to understand how biologists tackle problems, and how they finally arrive to the conclusions. Very interesting lectures that I don't even wanna miss one.
reviews.comment_grading:
Decent grading. I got a B+ (I am year 3 so I think this grade is fine for me). I did not study much for this course, just normally attending lectures and actively thinking during lecture time. I do not care that much about the grade, I treasure more what I have learnt from this course.

But I don't suggest you to take this course if you are not truly interested, as the people attending this course are pretty competitive and mostly very interested in the content so they are willing to do a lot of extra studies.

45% Final open book exam
15% Group presentation
20% Data-mining assignment
10% Written report for the group presentation
reviews.comment_workload: In general the workload is not much, no midterms and final is open book. But the group presentation, the assignment and the written report has close deadlines, which is around the final period. But you can prepare earlier, as the topic of data mining assignment is given very early.

reviews.author: Hafei
reviews.title: Advance knowledge and experiment design required
reviews.comment_content: very interesting.There are different kinds of genetic disease and their mechanisms.Also different experimentnal design and skills are taught to diagnose them. Many knowledge are advanced and new which is very satisfying.
reviews.comment_teaching: It is taught in a case study approach.Through different cases, papers, analysis is carried out and different knowledge and medical practices are discussed.
reviews.comment_grading: Just like many advance lifs course, the grading is fair or not very good. If you are more or less lie within the mean, you can expect to get a C+ or less.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is pretty huge.Throughout the semester, one group presentation about a particular genetic disease is required that you are expected to browse through different data bases and read papers.Then a 5 page summary or paper for this presentation is required. And each individual is also required to do a data mining on a different genetic disease as well.
